page.title: Legal Status & Legality
page.subtitle: A detailed legal analysis of the situation in Germany and the EU

intro.lead: The legal situation of Kava (Piper methysticum) in Europe is complex and often misunderstood. According to current legal assessment, Kava is not a Novel Food in Germany and the EU and is therefore generally marketable, provided it is not marketed as a medicinal product.
intro.alertText: Kava was consumed in significant quantities in the EU before May 15, 1997. Therefore, it does not fall under the Novel Food Regulation (EU) 2015/2283 and does not require approval as a novel food.

novelFood.title: The Novel Food Status
novelFood.p1: The crucial question for the marketability of Kava as a food or dietary supplement in the EU is whether it is classified as a "novel food" (Novel Food). The Novel Food Regulation defines all foods as novel that were not used for human consumption in significant quantities in the EU before May 15, 1997.
novelFood.p2: A current legal opinion comes to the clear conclusion: Kava is not a Novel Food.

items.label: Medicinal product approval before 1997:
items.text: Kava was officially approved in Germany long before 1997 (Commission E Monograph 1990).

items.label: Market presence:
items.text: At least 24 pharmaceutical companies sold Kava extracts in Europe before 1997 (Source: ETC Group).

items.label: Distribution:
items.text: Products like "Antares" or "Kavasporal forte" were widely available and freely accessible.

items.label: No approval requirement:
items.text: Since Kava is not a Novel Food, it does not have to undergo a lengthy approval process.

items.label: Marketability:
items.text: Kava products can be legally sold as food or dietary supplements.

items.label: Burden of proof:
items.text: Authorities would have to prove that Kava was not consumed – which is impossible given the historical facts.

germany.title: The Situation in Germany
germany.intro: Germany has a unique history regarding Kava. The development can be divided into three phases:

phases.title: Phase 1: The Golden Age (until 2001)
phases.text: Kava was a popular and recognized herbal remedy. The Commission E (BfArM) confirmed its efficacy for nervous anxiety disorders in 1990. There were numerous approved preparations available in pharmacies and drugstores.

phases.title: Phase 2: The Ban (2002–2014)
phases.text: Due to suspected cases of liver damage (which were later deemed questionable), the BfArM revoked the approvals for Kava medicinal products in 2002. This led to a de facto market ban.

phases.title: Phase 3: The Repeal (from 2014/2019)
phases.text: Courts declared the blanket ban unlawful. In 2019, the revocation of approvals was finally lifted. Today, it is clear: The ban applied to medicinal products. As food (considering the non-novel food status), Kava has never been explicitly banned.

distinction.title: Distinction: Medicinal Products vs. Food
distinction.p1: An important legal aspect is the distinction. Kava cannot be sold as a medicinal product in Germany without having the appropriate approval (which currently few manufacturers apply for). It is therefore traded as food, dietary supplement, or ingredient.
distinction.p2: Merchants may not make health-related claims ("helps against anxiety disorders") as this would classify the product as a presentation medicinal product. Claims regarding general relaxation or tradition are, however, to be assessed within the framework of food law.

eu.title: The EU Legal Situation
eu.intro: At the EU level, there is no central ban on Kava. However, regulation is inconsistent. The following map provides an overview of the current situation in various European countries:

rows.details: Marketable as food/dietary supplement (not a Novel Food). Medicinal product status possible, but rare.
The old ban was explicitly lifted in 2018. Kava is freely available.
Sale for human consumption is still officially restricted, possession and import for personal use is often tolerated.
Strict interpretation of medicinal product laws, but no explicit Novel Food ban.

conclusion.title: Conclusion & Recommendation
conclusion.text: The legal panic of the early 2000s is scientifically and legally outdated. Kava is legally available in Germany and many parts of the EU. However, consumers should ensure to purchase Noble Kava from certified vendors to ensure quality and safety.
conclusion.disclaimerText: This information does not constitute legal advice. The legal situation may change. We recommend that merchants and importers seek legal advice before engaging in commercial trade.

items.question: Can I order Kava from the USA?
items.answer:
In principle, yes, but with caution. Since Kava is not listed as a narcotic in Germany, importing for personal use is not punishable under the Narcotics Act (BtMG).

However, customs may intercept the shipment if there is suspicion that it is an unapproved medicinal product. In this case, the shipment is usually returned to the sender or destroyed. It is advisable to order from European vendors who have already imported the goods into the EU.

items.question: Is possession of Kava illegal?
items.answer: No. Possession of Kava root powder is legal in Germany and most EU countries. Kava is not subject to the Narcotics Act (BtMG). It is a legal herbal substance.

items.question: Why is Kava not available in pharmacies?
items.answer:
After the ban of 2002 (which was lifted in 2014/2015), many pharmaceutical manufacturers did not renew their approvals as the process is costly and cumbersome.

Currently, there are hardly any approved Kava finished medicinal products in Germany. Kava is therefore primarily available as a raw material (e.g., as a "bath additive" or ethnobotanical demonstration material) or in some cases as a dietary supplement (in other EU countries).

items.question: Can I take Kava on the plane?
items.answer:
Within the EU, this is generally unproblematic as long as it is for personal use.

When traveling outside the EU (e.g., to Australia, New Zealand, or the USA), you should check the import regulations there. In some countries (e.g., Singapore, Japan), stricter rules may apply. Check with the respective embassy before traveling.

items.question: Is Kava a "Novel Food"?
items.answer:
According to prevailing legal opinion: No.

A "Novel Food" is a food that was not consumed in significant quantities in the EU before May 15, 1997. However, since Kava was already present in Europe long before this cut-off date (also as food/pleasure product in health food stores) and as a medicinal product, the Novel Food Regulation does not apply here. Nevertheless, some authorities occasionally attempt to classify Kava as such, which is legally contestable.
